fields.body:
I feel like I can’t make things good enough for myself. This of course leads to a whole set of other problems, like wondering what people I’ve never even met, people I don't even know, people I shouldn't even care about, will think. I go so far as to even imagine how they might criticize it. I can't even begin to explain how much this imaginary criticism can eat at me at times. Sometimes I’ll even lie awake all night, wondering what I could add to make sure Random Internet Person I Don’t Even Know might like it. 

I’ve set such high standards for myself, nothing I do is able to meet my own level of quality. It causes me to get stuck in this endless loop of building something and then quickly discarding it because it wasn’t “good enough” and the entire process would start over.

The truth is that emptiness still remains today. And maybe it wont ever go away. But I’ve come to realize nothing I ever make will be perfect. It will never please everyone, and I have to learn to settle with good enough. Sometimes good enough is good enough.
fields.title: Good Enough.
fields.summary_html:
Nearly a decade ago I launched ULost, my first startup, providing affordable web hosting to everyone. It wasn’t anything groundbreaking, but what it did, it did well. At it’s peak, I hosted nearly 500 paid monthly subscribers, and thousands of free accounts. But due to a series of unfortunate events and trusting the wrong people, I eventually was forced to make a tough decision: shut it down, or rebuild from the ground up. Working 14 hour days doing tech support, managing servers, and web development took alot out of me. I didn’t want to do it anymore. I couldn’t do it anymore. I was burnt out. After disappearing for a few days to clear my head, I decided to close up shop.

For years to follow, I became depressed. I felt empty. I floated from project to project. I tried to find something, anything to fill the void inside of me. No matter what I did, nothing was able to fill that passion I once had. When I would sit down to write, I couldn’t think of anything profound to say. When I tried to design, after spending hours drawing, only to end up with nothing to show. A screen just as blank as it was when I started.

fields.body: While I use a feed reader almost religiously, it's often times daunting reading though all the latest news about video games. The idea was to create something that I could quickly scan the headlines from some of the most popular video game sites. [jadedgamer.net](http://jadedgamer.net) does just that. It's a mix of python and Django framework. And thanks to the awesome [superfeedr](http://superfeedr.com/) service, whenever something is published, the news is automatically pushed right to the site. It's pretty basic (and a little hacky) right now, but if enough people show interest in it, I hope to build some social features into it, like being able to save your favorite stories, and ultimately, some kind of recommendation system and the ability for anyone to customize it how they want. For now, feel free to create an account, and if you have an interesting gaming site you think should be added, submit the feed to the community group. [jadedgamer.net](http://jadedgamer.net/ "Jaded Gamer")

fields.body:
I ruined the Diablo II Economy.

Ive grown up on Blizzard games. Warctaft and Diablo were some of the first PC games I've ever played. In fact, it was Diablo and battle.net chat that got me into programming. Between the lack of any real security, the open source examples of battle.net chat bots and numerous tutorials, it was a great way to get started programming. 

By the time I was 15, I grew bored of actually playing the games. I probably spent more time in Visual Studio reverse engineering the bnet protocol than actually playing. We idled in the Diablo public channel "Bounty Hunters". We had contests to see who could make our bots do more interesting things. Seeing who could make bots to automaiclly win games in Starcraft, or lose the most in Warcraft (and so ulost bot was born. But thats another story). 

Around this time hackers had started making maphacks that went undetectable by Warden, Blizzard's security in Diablo II. There were exploits to duplicate items. We even made our own corrupted items with absurd abilities. Sure, it made the game easy to play, but that wasnt the point. It wasnt about playing the game. It was about finding new things to do with the game. It was a new challange. To see if it could be done. 

But like all challenges, it eventually was conquered, and I was bored again. And being the immature teenager I was, I became greedy. I wanted more. Now, at this point in time on the battle.net, keyloggers and viruses were everywhere. It was common to go in a public chat channel, and see all kinds of spam and phishing attcks of people trying to steal your account. While theri were a few uneducated people that fell for it, the majority of battle.net was clever enough to not fall for the "God mode" or "dupe" hacks that floated around. That is, until I stepped in. 

I decided to take the average phishing attack further. The idea was, What if I actually made a program that did just what all the fakes promised? I started with something simple. A maphack. A simple "Click here to reveal the map" button.  And you know what? It actually worked. It was even undetectable by Diablo 2's Security protocol, Warden.  Then I passed it around. Using different usernames, I posted it in chat channels and forums. Pretty much where everyone else spamed.  

A while before I wrote the maphack, I had discovered a pretty simple "God Mode" exe file someone was using to phish for passwords. It was a simple little app written in Visual Basic. It did nothhing more than a simple key logger that connected to a polish smtp server and sent an email with all the keystroked it captured every 5 minutes or so. Using a standard hex editor I was able to find the username/password and smtp server address. Why was this important?

fields.body: I started traveling around rather frequently over the past couple years. More than I ever have my entire life. In that time I've taken hundreds of photos. Most of them bad. A few however turn out pretty well sometimes. For some time I wanted a way to document some of my adventures in Seattle. After having a little free time over this past weekend, I finally setup a photo blog that does just that. Powered Jekyll and hosted on Github, its a pretty simple, static setup. The source is freely available on my github page, or you can check out the site live: [seattle.underlost.net](http://seattle.underlost.net/ "Hello Seattle")

fields.body: Do not let your fire go out, spark by irreplaceable spark, in the hopeless swamps of the approximate, the not-quite, the not-yet, the not-at-all. Do not let the hero in your soul perish, in lonely frustration for the life you deserved, but have never been able to reach. Check your road and the nature of your battle. The world you desired can be won, it exists, it is real, it is possible, it’s yours

fields.body: For a while, I've been thinking about having some sort of self-hosted mini steam profile so I could play around with the Steam Web API. Over the weekend I decided it was time to take a break from some other stuff and give it a go. The result is [Vapor](http://vapor.underlost.net/tf2/underlost), a Django/Python web app. The original plan was just to have it for my profile only, but after talking to a couple people, I've decided I'll be moving it to its own website, with a mobile version coming eventually. You can give it a try right now with your own profile, simply by going to: http:://vapor.underlost.net/tf2/SteamID. ### To do: * Portal 2 Backpacks * Dota2 Backpacks? * Sort functionality * TF2 loadouts * Plus More * Mobile version

fields.body:
For some time, I’ve held onto jadedgamer.net, unsure of what to really do with it. At the time it seemed like a good domain to have for something. It started as a gaming blog. A place for me to post share my comments on links I would find through out the day. Something along the lines of Daring Fireball, but with less Apple, and more video games. Surprisingly, it takes a rather large investment of time and discipline to maintain. 

I kept this up for about 6 months before I realized tumblr was better for my situation. Tools for posting were just quicker compared to Movable Type or Wordpress. Over time I decided it would just be easier to merge it with my existing [blog](http://blog.underlost.net "underlost blogs"). The site again became dorminet. 

Fast forward two years. I thought about selling the domain. I did get a couple offers. I became disinterested with the idea of having it be just another video game news site, in witch the content would be so fleeting. I wanted it to be something that could withstand some amount of time. Something that would still be interesting to read years for now. 

About the time I had received my tickets for PAX Prime 2011, I realized something. I was looking at it wrong. The primary focus of the site shouldn’t be the games themselves. No, instead I decided to go after something most sites overlook. The love of video games. 

Quickly I slapped something together as PAX drew near. I spammed the link through my 3DS, letting anyone I met via [StreetPass](http://www.giantbomb.com/streetpass-mii-plaza/61-34857/) know of the new site. Of the 800 or so that saw the link, about 300 actually visited the site. Not bad for such a tacky marketing ploy. About 150 even left their thoughts. 

After returning home, I refined the idea, renamed it to a more suitable name, and built a new prototype. After pitching it to a few other developers, they thought it was an interesting concept as well. That brings us to today. So just what is it, or what will it become?

- A Life Well Played asks a simple question. Why play video games? Nothing else. This isnt a question for just the first issue. The entire focus on the magazine is to discover why we play games. We’ll be talking to producers, developers, modders, and gamers alike. 

- It will be a print magazine foremost. I want to create something people will want to keep, and proudly display. There will be a PDF version available, and I think you’ll like some of the interesting interactive HTML5 features Im working on for the web version, but print will be the main focus.

- The first issue will be a limited run, somewhere between 1000 and 2500 copies. If they sell out, we’ll look into doing a reprint.

- I hope to get the first issue released by May 2012. This is not a set date (yet) and may change. The first issues success will determine how frequently new issues (and reprints) are created. 

There are still a lot more details to follow, and we’ll have a list of the interviewees soon. A lot more details will be revealed in January 2012. For now, I ask to follow along on twitter (@jadedgamer) if you would like to learn more. I can promise you won’t be spammed, and you’ll be the first to know more about the initial release.

fields.body:
__I Use This__ is a a frequently updated page of hardware, software, and services I use on a regular basis. It’s things I find personally useful. 

### Hardware

My main setup is a custom built Intel I5 Sandy Bridge with 8GB ram and a Sapphire Radeon 6850 video card on a Gigabyte motherboard. The parts were chosen specifically with a Mac Hacintosh build in mind. 

Aside from that, I also use an an old HP notebook powered by Windows 7 for Skyping and testing web site compatibility in Internet Explorer. When I’m mobile, I’m usually equipped with my 8GB iPhone, and Asus EeePC netbook, running the latest version of Ubuntu and the preview build of Windows 8. 

### Software

For image editing, I use Photoshop CS5, Illustrator CS5, along with Flare and Analog. I’ll sometimes dabble in Xcode (Mac) or Visual Studio (Windows), but the majority of my time developing is done through Macrabbit’s beautiful Espresso software. And although discontinued, I use their CSSEdit for making quick visual changes, with Git used to deploy and keep track of changes.

* __Chat/Communcation:__ Adium, Skype, Steam, Twitterific.
* __FTP:__ Cyberduck
* __Music:__ iTunes, Pandora One
* __Browsers:__ Chrome, along side Firefox Nightly and Webkit. 

### Services 

Since Heroku started opening up their services to other platforms, I’ve moved the majority of my python/django powered sites to their service, while still relying on Media Temple for serving static content and MySQL/PostgreSQL hosting, as well as DNS management for all my domains. Calendars, documents and everything else is managed with Google Apps.
